content.prompt:
• The polar function is a portion of a loop with a horizontal orientation.
  • Moving from the center to the outside of the grid:
    • The function curves from 0 upward and to the right.
    • The function passes radii of 2 and 4 and then reaches a maximum distance from the polar axis.
    • The function then curves downward and to the right until it reaches the radius of 6.
  • The polar function is a portion of a loop with a horizontal orientation.
  • Moving from the center to the outside of the polar grid:
    • The function curves from 0 downward and to the right.
    • The function passes radii of 2 and 4 and then reaches a maximum distance from the polar axis.
    • The function then curves upward and to the right until it reaches the radius of 6.
  • The polar function is a portion of a loop with a horizontal orientation.
  • Moving from the center to the outside of the polar grid:
    • The function curves from 0 upward and to the left.
    • The function passes radii of 2 and 4 and then reaches a maximum distance from the polar axis.
    • The function then curves downward and to the left until it reaches the radius of 6.
  • The polar function is a portion of a loop with a horizontal orientation.
  • Moving from the center to the outside of the polar grid:
    • The function curves from 0 downward and to the left.
    • The function passes radii of 2 and 4 and then reaches a maximum distance from the polar axis.
    • The function then curves upward and to the left until it reaches the radius of 6.

Consider the graph of the polar function r=fθ, where fθ=-6cosθ, in the polar coordinate system. Which of the following is the graph of r=fθ for 0≤θ≤π2 ?

skill.text: Skill 2.B: Construct equivalent graphical, numerical, analytical, and verbal representations of functions that are useful in a given mathematical or applied context, with and without technology.
